Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was finishing my lunch break. It was Mom, her voice trembling as she asked if I could talk for a minute. “Your father’s been quiet lately. I just… I need to know you’re there for us,” she said. I promised I’d call back soon, but as I hung up, my pager blared—emergency in the ICU. A life-support machine was flashing red, the nurses’ faces tight with worry. I rushed down the hall, my mind split in two. My parents needed me to check in, to be the son who listens and reassures. But right now, a patient’s life depended on my hands, my focus, my technical skill. I could almost hear Mom’s voice in my head, asking if everything was okay, while the machine’s alarm demanded my immediate attention. My heart pounded as I stood outside the ICU, torn between the call I needed to make and the machine I needed to fix, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
